Fig. 1 Two-stage reaction system for LDPE pyrolysis coupling with steam reforming. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns of the calcined Ni catalysts on various supports: (a) Ni/Al2O3, (b) Ni/SiO2, (c) Ni/MgO, (d) Ni/TiO2, (e) Ni/Y2O3, (f) Ni/CeO2 and (g) Ni/ZSM-5. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 DTG curves of the fresh Ni catalysts during TPR: (a) Ni/Al2O3, (b) Ni/SiO2, (c) Ni/MgO, (d) Ni/TiO2, (e) Ni/Y2O3, (f) Ni/CeO2 and (g) Ni/ZSM-5. Residues and Resource Reclamation Centre (R3C) Nanyang Environment and Water Research Institute Nanyang Technological University 1 Cleantech Loop, Clean Tech One 637141 Singapore Graphical abstract Syngas is a valuable intermediate for sustainable management of waste plastics, which can be converted to new monomers and chemicals. In this work, Ni catalysts were studied for syngas recovery via steam reforming of low-density polyethylene (LDPE) pyrolysis volatiles on various supports, such as Al2O3, MgO, CeO2, Y2O3, TiO2, SiO2 and ZSM-5. Two commercial catalysts (NiAl and NiCaAl) were used for comparison. The supports exhibited distinct effects on the catalytic activity, selectivity and coke formation. Ni/CeO2, Ni/Y2O3, Ni/Al2O3, NiAl and NiCaAl showed high syngas yield but these catalysts were prone to coke formation. Ni/MgO, Ni/TiO2, Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZSM-5 were the least active. The obtained H2/CO ratios were correlated with CO selectivity, revealing the unique impacts of supports on syngas composition via water-gas shift reaction. Compared with commercial NiAl, our work demonstrated that the prepared Ni catalysts on Al2O3 and MgO were suitable candidates for steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis volatiles. Keywords Polyethylene Steam reforming Syngas Support effect Metal-support interaction 1 Introduction Over 6.3 billion tonnes of waste plastics (half of which are polyolefins) have been generated worldwide, causing reduced capacity of landfills and environmental pollution [1]. Chemical recycling via thermal treatment is regarded as a potential solution for waste plastics management [2,3]. Furthermore, the conversion of waste plastics into valuable products can reduce the dependence on non-renewable resources, such as natural gas and crude oil, and achieve circularity of economy [4]. Pyrolysis is a typical thermal process suitable for decomposition of polyolefins, resulting mainly in oil and non-condensable hydrocarbons [5,6]. These products can be further reformed in a downstream catalytic process to produce syngas, a valuable feedstock for synthesis of H2, ethylene, propylene, methanol, dimethyl ether, aromatics and other chemicals. During reforming, pyrolysis products react with steam (steam reforming), CO2 (dry reforming) or their mixtures at high temperatures (e.g., 600−850 °C), forming syngas mainly consisting of CO and H2. Ni-based monometallic and bimetallic catalysts have been investigated for steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis volatiles, with supports including zeolites [7,8], MCM-41 [9], Al2O3 [10–14], CaO-C [15], and ZrO2 [16]. The previous reports suggest that besides the reaction conditions and feedstock, product yields are highly influenced by catalyst composition. Specifically, support material can influence the physicochemical properties of the catalyst, such as surface area, pore structure, acidity-basicity, reducibility and the metal-support interaction. These properties are influential factors on the catalytic activity, selectivity and deactivation behavior. Generally, the supports with high surface area and proper pore structure are beneficial for high reforming activity with high metal dispersion; basic and reducible oxides (e.g., MgO, La2O3 and CeO2) can improve catalyst stability and activity by minimizing coke formation [17–19]. Additionally, metal-support interaction determines the reducibility of metal species and the formation of unique interfacial sites, playing important roles in catalyst activity and stability [20–23]. Previously, it was reported that the chemical composition of reformate gas has a significant impact on catalytic activity. Barbarias et al. [24] studied steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis model compounds (n-hexane, 1-hexene, tetradecane and toluene), showing that olefinic and aromatic compounds caused faster catalyst deactivation than paraffinic compounds, due to the intensified formation of amorphous coke. Additionally, it was demonstrated that linear hydrocarbons presented higher reactivity than olefinic and aromatic compounds, and a decrease in reactivity with higher carbon number was observed. During steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis volatiles at high temperature, the feed complexity requires more active and robust catalysts compared to the model compounds. It is generally acknowledged that the support material could impact the catalyst activity and deactivation behaviors. The influence of supports on Ni catalyst activity and stability has been investigated for tri-reforming (in the presence of steam, CO2 and O2) of methane [25], steam reforming of bio-oil [26] and wood biomass-derived pyrolysis volatiles [27–29]. However, a systematic study is still lacking on how the catalyst supports could affect the catalytic performance during steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis volatiles. In this work, Ni catalysts are prepared by wet impregnation of seven supports (Al2O3, MgO, CeO2, Y2O3, TiO2, SiO2 and ZSM-5) and tested for syngas production from LDPE via thermal pyrolysis and steam reforming. The catalytic performance is compared with two commercial Ni catalysts which are used for methane reforming. Characterization of materials by XRD, TPR, FESEM, TPO, XPS and Raman spectroscopy was carried out to investigate the effects of supports on the reforming activity, selectivity and coke formation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Ni catalysts Ni catalysts (10 wt.%) were prepared by wet impregnation method. In a typical synthesis, Ni(NO3)3·6H2O (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 97.0 %) was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water in a crucible made of Al2O3. 1 g of catalyst supports, i.e. Al2O3 (Fluka 06290, particle size 0.05−0.15 mm, basic pH 9.5 ± 0.5), SiO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, nanopowder, 10−20 nm particle size, 99.5 % trace metals basis), CeO2 (Sigma-Aldrich, nanopowder, < 50 nm particle size, 99.95 % trace rare earth metals basis), MgO (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, ≥ 98.5 %), Y2O3 (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd), ZSM-5 (Alfa Aesar, powder, SiO2:Al2O3 mole ratio 23:1) and TiO2 (VP AEROPERL P 25/20) was added to the Ni2+ solution. The mixture was stirred for 24 h and then the water was evaporated over a hotplate. The solids were then dried and calcined in a muffle furnace. Calcination at 1000 °C for 6 h was applied as high temperature treatment can benefit stronger metal-support interaction [30,31]. The calcined powders were compressed, crushed and sieved to obtain catalysts with a sieve fraction of 212–300 μm. Two commercial Ni catalysts named NiAl (6-holes monoliths from Xian Sunward Aeromat Co., China) and NiCaAl (19 × 19 × 10 mm rings from Pingxiang Hualian Chemical Ceramic Co., China) were crushed, sieved, and tested to compare the catalytic performance with the synthesized catalysts. The Ni loading was 16.8 wt.% and 11.3 wt.% for NiAl and NiCaAl, respectively, as determined by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The content of other components in the commercial catalysts can be found elsewhere [32]. 2.2 Material characterization The crystalline phases in the fresh and spent samples were investigated using powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Bruker AXS D8 diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The morphology was studied using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEOL JSM-7600F). The average Ni crystallite size (nm) of the spent Ni catalysts was estimated using the Scherrer equation: (1) L = 0.89λ/(β(θ)*cosθ) where L is the crystallite size (nm), λ the X-ray wavelength (nm), θ the Bragg diffraction angle (°), and β(θ) the FWHM (rad) [33]. The Ni particle size was averaged over the calculated values from the diffraction angles (2θ) at approximately 44, 52 and 76°. The content of Ni in the catalysts was measured by using an ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer Optima 8300). Namely, 0.1 g of Ni catalyst was digested in a 3 mL of 69 % HNO3 (Honeywell 17512) and 9 mL of fuming HCl (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥ 37 %) mixture under microwave irradiation at 180 °C for 20 min. After cooling down, the solution was filtered with a 0.45 μm PVDF syringe filter and diluted with deionized water to a volume of 50 mL. 1 mL of the mixture was further diluted ten times and sent for analysis in the ICP-OES. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the fresh Ni catalysts was performed by reducing the calcined catalysts with 5 vol.% H2/N2 in a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA/DSC2, Mettler Toledo). In each reduction, approximately 10 mg of sample was heated to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 under a constant flow of 80 mL min−1 of 5 vol.% H2/N2. Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) of the spent Ni catalysts was performed by oxidizing the spent catalysts with 60 mL min−1 of air in a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA, NETZSCH STA_449_F3_Jupiter, protection gas N2 at 40 mL min−1) from 50 to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1. The coke content was estimated by the mass loss (wt.%) during TPO of the spent catalysts. The carbon species of the spent catalysts were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer) equipped with a dual anode monochromatic Kα extraction source. CASA XPS software was used for the deconvolution of the XPS spectra after correcting the binding energies of all the elements against the adventitious carbon C1s core level at 284.8 eV. Raman spectroscopy was collected by a Raman Spectrometer (XploRA PLUS, Horiba Scientific, Japan) coupled with a 532 nm laser source. 2.3 Catalyst performance during steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles Pyrolysis and catalytic steam reforming of pyrolysis volatiles from pure low-density polyethylene (LDPE, PTT Global Chemical Public Co. Ltd., Thailand) were carried out in a two-stage reactor system as shown in Fig. 1 . The pyrolysis reactor made of stainless steel (outer diameter of 25.4 mm) and reforming reactor made of a quartz tube (outer diameter of 25 mm) were externally heated by temperature-controlled electric furnaces. Reaction temperatures were 500 °C and 800 °C for the pyrolysis and reforming stages, respectively, which were consistent with those used in other studies [12,34]. The selected reforming temperature was also consistent with the industrial practice of steam reforming of natural gas, which is typically carried out at 800−900 °C [35]. Quartz reactor was used for the reforming stage to avoid coke deposition on reactor wall. The stainless steel tubing connecting the two reactors was heated at 400 °C to minimize any volatile condensation. N2 was introduced as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 200 mL min−1 to remove volatiles and prevent wax formation at the bottom of the pyrolysis reactor. In each test, 2 g of LDPE was placed in a borosilicate glass bottle (outer diameter of 18 mm, height of 7 mm), which was supported at the center of the heating zone by a stainless steel tube. To keep the reforming reactions away from the equilibrium and mass diffusion limitations, 0.1 g of catalyst particles (catalyst to LDPE ratio of 0.05) was diluted with 2 g of Al2O3 particles (mineral corundum, 300–425 μm, XRD pattern shown in Fig. S1), and the mixture was placed on quartz wool held by a smaller quartz tube inside the reforming reactor. The bed was heated to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 20 °C min−1 under N2 (200 mL min−1) and then reduced with 50 mL min−1 H2 for 20 min to activate the catalyst. After catalyst reduction, LDPE pyrolysis was started. The temperature of the pyrolysis reactor was increased from room temperature to 500 °C at a ramp rate of 20 °C min−1. When the temperature of the pyrolysis reactor reached 300 °C, steam was introduced into the reforming reactor by a peristaltic pump (Masterflex) at a feeding rate of 0.2 g min−1. The reaction time was optimized through two sets of blank experiments (with and without steam) using 2 g of Al2O3 particles as the bed material. Fig. S2 shows that once pyrolysis temperature of 500 °C was reached, a high concentration of light hydrocarbons was produced within 20 min for both non-catalytic thermal cracking and steam reforming. Based on these data, the steam injection continued for 20 min at 500 °C, corresponding to a steam/LDPE mass ratio of 2. The catalytic tests for each sample were triplicated. After reforming, the products passed through condensation and drying units consisted of ice-cooled glass bottles and a drying column filled with anhydrous CaCl2 beads (< 7 mm). The remaining gases were collected in 20 L gas bags for analysis. The concentrations of H2, CO, CO2, CH4 and C2-C5 hydrocarbons were measured by a calibrated gas chromatograph (Agilent 7890B, USA) equipped with one flame ionization and two thermal conductivity detectors. To reduce the mass loss during sample collection, the masses of residue and liquid were calculated as the mass differences of the quartz reactor (with the catalyst bed) and condenser bottles before and after the reaction. The amount of each gas (mol) was calculated using N2 as the internal standard: (2) n i = y i * n N 2 y N 2 where ni and yi are the amounts of each gas and the measured gas fraction, respectively. The gas yield of H2, CO and CO2 (mol g-LDPE−1) were calculated as: (3) Y i = n i m L D P E where mLDPE is the mass of LDPE (g). The product distribution (C-mol.%) in CO, CO2 and the gaseous hydrocarbons (CH4, C2H4, C2H6 and C3H6) was defined as: (4) D i = c i n i ∑ c i n i * 100 % where ci is the carbon number of each hydrocarbon and equals 1 for CO and CO2; ∑ c i n i is the total amount (mol) of detected carbon in the gaseous products. CO selectivity was calculated as: (5) S C O = n C O n C O + n C O 2 * 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst properties The prepared Ni catalysts were characterized by XRD and TPR to investigate the metal interaction with the supports. Fig. 2 depicts the XRD patterns of calcined samples and the obtained phase components are summarized in Table S1. Diffraction peaks of NiO (PDF #47-1049) were identified in the patterns of SiO2, Y2O3, CeO2 and ZSM-5 supported samples, suggesting the relatively weak interaction between the Ni2+ species and the supports. In contrast, stronger interaction was observed in TiO2, Al2O3 and MgO supported catalysts. TiO2 reacted with NiO during the high-temperature calcination to generate a new NiTiO3 phase (PDF #33-0960). The catalyst calcination at high temperature also facilitated the dissolution of Ni2+ in Al2O3 and MgO supports, forming NiAl2O4-Al2O3 and MgO-NiO solid solutions. The metal interaction with the supports was also studied by TPR carried out in a thermogravimetric apparatus. Higher reduction temperature corresponding to lower catalyst reducibility generally indicates stronger metal-support interaction [36]. The differential thermogravimetry (DTG) curves in Fig. 3 show that the mass loss was in the range of 300−500 °C for SiO2, Y2O3 and CeO2 supported catalysts, which is in good agreement with the reduction temperature of bulk NiO [37]. This confirms that SiO2, Y2O3 and CeO2 have the weakest interaction with NiO (reduction temperature < 500 °C) among the studied supports. The TPR peaks at 649 and 797 °C on Ni/SiO2 and Ni/CeO2 are related to the reduction of Ni2SiO4 [38] and CeO2 [39], respectively. In case of weak interaction, Ni2+ is free to migrate across the support surface and may agglomerate to form large Ni particles catalyzing coke formation [40]. Ni/ZSM-5 presented a wide profile of Ni2+ reduction from 350 to 650 °C which is attributed to the varied interaction strength on the outer surface and in the channels. The reduction peak of Ni2+ species on ZSM-5 at ∼407 °C matches well with the reduction peak in Ni/SiO2, which can be ascribed to bulk NiO on the surface of ZSM-5; while the peak at ∼600 °C can be ascribed to the reduction of Ni2+ oligomeric species located inside the channels [41]. The observation of a weak interaction similar with Ni/SiO2 on the surface of ZSM-5 was probably caused by the high content of SiO2 in ZSM-5, and the stronger interaction in the channels possibly originated from the confinement effect of micropores that hindered the growth of Ni particle. The TPR peak at ∼776 °C for Ni/Al2O3 agrees well with the reduction temperature of NiAl2O4 [42], as NiAl2O4 has much lower lattice oxygen activity than that of NiO. The lower Ni2+ reducibility in NiAl2O4 resulted from the stronger Ni-O-Al bond, compared to the Ni-O-Ni bond in bulk NiO or NiO weekly bonded with the support. For MgO, a small mass loss is observed at 293 °C, which can be ascribed to CO2 desorption from the MgO support [43,44]. Activation of the dissolved Ni2+ was difficult under the present TPR conditions for Ni/MgO due to the formation of MgO-NiO solution (Fig. 2). The finding is in agreement with Kumar et al. [25], and it was also demonstrated that NiO-MgO interaction highly depended on calcination temperature [45]. For TiO2 support, NiTiO3 was reduced to Ni-TiO2 at 530−650 °C suggesting an intermediate strength of NiO-support interaction compared to other supports. The observed reduction temperature for NiTiO3 is comparable to that reported previously [29,46]. The TPR curves of commercial NiAl and NiCaAl catalysts were described in other reports [32,47]. The reduction temperatures of both catalysts were lower than that of Ni/Al2O3, suggesting weaker metal-support interaction compared to the prepared Ni/Al2O3 after high-temperature calcination. According to the TPR results, catalyst reducibility decreased in the order of Ni/CeO2 > Ni/Y2O3 > Ni/SiO2 > Ni/ZSM-5 > Ni/TiO2 > Ni/Al2O3 > Ni/MgO. Additionally, it was seen that the mass loss during TPR varied from the samples, as shown in Fig. S3. Ni/MgO presented the lowest mass loss of 0.7 % from Ni2+ reduction. Considering the consistent Ni content in the prepared catalysts (measured by ICP-OES, Table S2), the low mass loss from Ni/MgO indicated a low degree of reducibility as a result of MgO-NiO solid solution formation after calcination at 1000 °C. The low reducibility of Ni/MgO implicates that its catalytic activity may be limited by the low amount of Ni sites that can be activated by H2. Overall, the XRD and TPR results indicated that stronger metal interaction tended to form on ZSM-5, TiO2, Al2O3 and MgO, as compared to SiO2, CeO2 and Y2O3. This was consistent with the previous reports applying catalyst calcination at temperatures higher than 700 °C [25,29]. In contrast, the reduction of Ni species at low temperatures was also reported for Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/TiO2 calcined at 500 °C [27,31]. It is reasonable to suggest that catalyst reducibility depended not only on the nature of supports but also on the calcination temperature. 3.2 Effect of supports on the reforming activity The prepared Ni catalysts were used for steam reforming of pyrolysis volatiles from LDPE. Table 1 summarizes the product yields and mass balance for the blank experiment (non-catalytic steam reforming using Al2O3 particles) and experiments with catalysts. In all cases, the mass balance was above ∼94 %. Compared to the experiment using Al2O3 particles, higher gas yield and lower liquid yield were obtained with the Ni catalysts, confirming the effectiveness of pyrolysis volatiles conversion by catalytic steam reforming. Among the nine samples, considerable formation of residue was observed over NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3, suggesting more coke formation on these catalysts. Fig. 4 a shows the gas composition. In the experiment with Al2O3 particles, the conversion of hydrocarbons to CO and CO2 was insignificant (0.5 mol.% and 0.3 mol.%), leaving a gas mixture consisting of mainly CH4 (23.3 mol.%), C2-C5 hydrocarbons (60.8 mol.%) and H2 (15.1 mol.%). This result suggests that a catalyst is required for the steam reforming of pyrolysis volatile species. As shown in Fig. S2, C2H4, CH4, C3H6 and H2 are the main gaseous products obtained from the non-catalytic reforming (i.e., in both experiments with and without steam), while the gas before heat treatment at 800 °C would contain large quantities of hydrocarbons with larger numbers of carbon atoms [48]. Together with 15.1 mol.% H2 production, these results indicate that long-chain hydrocarbons partially underwent non-catalytic cracking during heating, which was also reported in the other study [49]. In the presence of catalysts, the H2 fraction increased from 15.1 mol.% to 45.6–57.1 mol.%. This process was accompanied by the appearance of CO (11.1–19.8 mol.%) and CO2 (3.7–8.7 mol.%) in the gas stream due to the oxidation of hydrocarbons by steam. The production of syngas consisting of H2, CO and CO2 varied depending on the supports as shown in Fig. 4b. Specifically, the syngas yield (used as a parameter reflecting the catalyst activity) decreased in the order of Ni/CeO2 > Ni/Al2O3 > Ni/Y2O3, NiAl > NiCaAl > Ni/MgO > Ni/TiO2 > Ni/SiO2 > Ni/ZSM-5. Several factors could contribute to the observed differences in activity. One of the factors is the strength of metal-support interaction. For instance, for Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3 having weak Ni-support interaction, the catalysts had a high degree of reducibility and more active sites could be generated resulting in high syngas yield. On the other hand, for Ni/Al2O3 with strong Ni-support interaction, the formation of fine Ni particles on Al2O3 could render the high activity. The Ni particle sizes were estimated by the Scherrer equation from the XRD results of the freshly reduced and spent catalysts (Figs. S4–S6, Table S1). The Ni particle size of the fresh Ni/Al2O3 was smaller than that of other catalysts (8.9 nm against 12.2–27.6 nm), resulting from the strong interaction of NiO with the support. The results coincide with a previous study reporting Ni particle size of 7.9 and 22.1 nm on Al2O3 and SiO2, respectively [50]. However, the strong metal-support interaction on Ni/MgO caused a low degree of Ni reducibility and thus decreased the catalytic activity. The drawback of weak metal-support interaction is that it can promote irreversible particle sintering, resulting in low catalytic activity [25]. The low syngas yield over Ni/SiO2 and Ni/TiO2 can be related to the formation of large Ni particles (Table S1) after H2 activation, due to the weak metal-support interaction. It is worth noting that the catalyst activity was influenced by not only the metal-support interaction but also the other effects of the supports, which were competitive to determine the overall catalyst performance. Compared with the catalysts with alumina supports, Ni/CeO2 was more active, which can be ascribed to the reducible properties of CeO2 that surface oxygen species can be formed to promote the dissociation of hydrocarbons [51]. For Ni/SiO2, Ni/ZSM-5 and Ni/TiO2, the activity was relatively low. The low syngas yield on Ni/SiO2 probably resulted from the oxidative deactivation by the steam, forming inactive NiO overlayer on the Ni particles. It was reported that steam can oxidize the surface of Ni particles on 20 wt.% Ni/SiO2 during steam reforming of CH4 at 500 °C [52]. The low activity on Ni/ZSM-5 suggested that the active sites in the channels of ZSM-5 may have limited access to the hydrocarbons with long carbon numbers due to the steric constraint of the micropores (10-ring pore windows with size of 0.53*0.56 nm and 0.51*0.55 nm [53]). In the case of Ni/TiO2, the reactivity was probably hindered by the high geometrical coverage of Ni particle surface by TiO2 encapsulation after catalyst reduction [31]. In brief, the supports have significant effects on the catalytic activity which can be ascribed to the unique metal-support interaction, pore structure and the active metal encapsulation. 3.3 Effect of supports on the selectivity During the steam reforming, the pyrolysis volatiles reacted via thermal and catalytic pathways, producing a gas mixture containing light hydrocarbons, CO, CO2 and H2. Fig. 5 displays the distribution of carbon in the gaseous products. During the experiment with Al2O3 particles, the carbon atoms were mainly contained in C2H4 (59.9 mol.%), C3H6 (18.6 mol.%) and CH4 (14.8 mol.%), suggesting that the production of lower olefins and methane was highly favored during the cracking of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles. The percentages in CO and CO2 were minimal (< 0.5 mol.%), indicating that steam reforming was insignificant in the absence of catalysts. The carbon distributed in other hydrocarbons was below 5 mol.%. Compared to the experiment with Al2O3 particles, the content of carbon in hydrocarbons was reduced during catalytic steam reforming. On the other hand, the content of carbon in CO and CO2 was significantly increased. Specifically, Ni/CeO2 that produced the highest syngas yield presented the lowest carbon content in hydrocarbons (32.6 mol.% in C2H4, 6.56 mol.% in C3H6 and 11.7 mol.% in CH4) but the highest in CO (29.4 mol.%) and CO2 (14.0 mol.%). The higher catalytic activity resulted in the lower carbon content in hydrocarbons for other supports as well. Ni/Y2O3, Ni/Al2O3, NiAl and NiCaAl had lower carbon content in the residual hydrocarbons. The observation agreed with the trend of syngas yields shown in Fig. 4b. From Fig. 5, the carbon content in C2H6 remained consistent and the content in CH4 was slightly reduced for the catalytic experiments. However, the carbon content in C2H4 and C3H6 was obviously decreased compared with that in CH4 and C2H6, especially over the catalysts with high activity. The varied changes in carbon contents indicate that the reactivity of light olefins was higher than that of alkanes during the catalytic steam reforming process. H2/CO ratio is an important parameter of the produced syngas for downstream application. According to Eq. (6), steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles shall generate syngas with a H2/CO ratio of 2. (6) ( C H 2 ) n + n H 2 O = n C O + 2 n H 2 However, the obtained H2/CO ratios were in the range of 2.7–4.4 (Fig. 6 a), depending on the catalyst supports. The obtained H2/CO ratio range was in good accordance with that from other syngas processes, such as steam reforming of natural gas and naphtha [54]. It should also be acknowledged that the H2/CO ratio depends on not only the catalysts but also the reaction conditions including steam to plastic ratio and reaction temperature. An insufficient steam injection can limit the steam reforming reaction but favor the production of carbon products, resulting in increased H2/CO ratios at a lower steam to plastic ratio [10,12]. The obtained H2/CO ratio from reforming at 800 °C was lower than the findings from reforming at 600−700 °C by Lopez et al. [55], reporting H2/CO ratio of 6.2–8.7 (calculated from the reported gas yields). Fig. 6b reveals the effect of supports on the CO selectivity and H2/CO ratio. It shows that the H2/CO ratio tends to decrease with increasing CO selectivity. Among the various catalysts, reducible CeO2 and TiO2 supported Ni catalysts showed lower CO selectivity than Ni/SiO2, Ni/Y2O3 and NiCaAl. The results are consistent with a previous study reporting high activity of CeO2 supported bimetallic Pt-Ni catalysts for water-gas shift reaction [56]. Specifically, Ni/TiO2 presented the highest H2/CO ratio and lowest CO selectivity, likely originating from the unique Ni-TiO2 interface. As reported by Xu et al. [22], interfacial Ni species in Ni/TiO2 participated in the dissociation of H2O molecule to generate H2, revealing interfacial synergistic catalysis toward water-gas shift reaction. 3.4 Coke formation on the Ni catalysts Coke deposits on the spent catalysts were characterized by FESEM, XRD, Raman spectroscopy, TPO and XPS. Fig. 7 shows the FESEM images of the spent catalysts. Carbon filaments with a diameter of ∼20 nm are observed on Ni/Al2O3, and the coke has irregular morphology and hollow capsule structures on NiCaAl, NiAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3. For catalysts with SiO2, MgO, TiO2 and ZSM-5 supports, coke morphology cannot be identified from the images. However, XRD diffraction peaks for graphitic carbon at ∼26° were observed in most of the spent catalysts (Figs. S5 and S6), confirming the formation of coke on these catalysts. The absence of carbon diffraction peaks in Ni/MgO, Ni/ZSM-5 and Ni/Al2O3 can be ascribed to the low amount of coke deposit or low carbon crystallinity. The concentration of defects in the coke deposit was analyzed by Raman spectra (Fig. S7). ID/IG ratios of 1.25–1.47 were obtained on NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3, indicating a high concentration of defects in the coke. The results were consistent with the previous work by Yao et al. [12], reporting that higher steam inputs led to the increased ID/IG ratio. During steam reforming, coke deposits have a high concentration of defects generated from the high steam/LDPE mass ratio of 2. The high concentration of defects suggests that the coke on the catalysts had good reactivity in the coke-intensive steam reforming process [57]. TPO was used to characterize the coke deposits as the oxidation temperature is influenced by the coke nature. Fig. 8 describes the TPO profiles and the association between the measured coke content and the oxidation peak temperatures. It can be observed that the oxidation peak tends to shift to a higher temperature with higher coke deposition. According to Ochoa et al. [40], oxidation at temperatures higher than 500 °C can be assigned to graphitic coke, while oxidation at lower temperatures was attributable to amorphous or encapsulating carbon species. For the catalysts with coke content higher than 10 wt.%, the oxidation peaks are higher than 550 °C except for Ni/Al2O3 (461 °C). The high temperatures for coke combustion indicate that the formation of graphitic coke is more favored than that of amorphous coke from LDPE pyrolysis volatiles. It should be noted that Ni oxidation during TPO may influence the accuracy of measured coke content by mass loss, particularly for the samples with low coke content (Ni/ZSM-5 and Ni/TiO2). The mass gain at around 428 °C on spent Ni/TiO2 (Fig. 8a) was ascribed to Ni oxidation. However, the signal for Ni oxidation was insignificant over the other catalysts with high coke content. The result indicates that the effect of Ni oxidation on the mass change was reduced as the coke content increased (which means less amount of oxidizable Ni0). The carbon species in the deposited coke were further analyzed by XPS. Fig. 9 shows the deconvolution of the high-resolution C1s core spectra of the spent catalysts, and the obtained fraction of various carbon species is summarized in Table 2 . The peaks centered at ∼283.0, 284.6 and 285.5 eV were assigned to CNi, CC and CC bonds, while the peaks beyond 286.4 eV derived from CO, CO and OCO bonds [58–60]. During steam reforming, the adsorption, diffusing, nucleation and precipitation of carbon atoms from the metallic particles are critical steps for coke formation [40]. The relatively high fraction of C-Ni bond in spent NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3 agrees well with their high activity for coke formation. The fraction of O-containing carbon species was used to evaluate coke combustion temperature in TPO (Fig. S8). It was shown that the coke was more resistant to combustion on NiCaAl, NiAl, Ni/CeO2, Ni/Y2O3 and Ni/ZSM-5, likely due to the lower fraction of O-containing groups in the coke. Combining the TPR and TPO results, it was found that the Ni catalysts (i.e., NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3) with weak metal-support interaction tended to form more coke during steam reforming. The observation is consistent with the findings by Nahil et al. [61] that a high yield of carbon products was obtained on a Ni–Mn–Al catalyst with weak metal-support interaction. In contrast to previous reports on catalyst modification with CeO2 for coke-resistant catalysts [19,62], coke formation on Ni/CeO2 was intensive. Severe carbon deposition on Ni/CeO2 was also reported during dry reforming of CH4, which was controlled by the strength of metal-support interaction depending on the Ni loading and calcination temperature [63,64]. The high coke formation on Ni/CeO2 can be ascribed to the formation of large Ni particle size (20.6 nm) caused by the weak metal-support interaction. The Ni particle size has important influence on the coke formation. According to Christensen et al. [65], the resistance to coke formation increases with smaller Ni particle size due to a higher saturation concentration of carbon. After the catalytic tests at 800 °C, the particle sizes were comparable for Ni/Al2O3, Ni/ZSM-5, Ni/SiO2, Ni/TiO2, and Ni/CeO2 (Table S1). The Ni particles were likely stabilized by the strong metal-support interaction in Ni/Al2O3 and the micropores of ZSM-5. For Ni/SiO2, Ni/TiO2, Ni/CeO2 with initial Ni particle size of approximately 20 nm, particle sintering was insignificant because of the lower mobility of large Ni particles on the supports [66]. In the cases of NiCaAl and Ni/Y2O3, the Ni particle size increased by 3−4 nm after reaction, suggesting a higher tendency of particle sintering on the catalysts having both weak metal-support interaction and small initial particle size. On the other hand, the Ni particle size on NiAl abnormally decreased from 27.6 to 21.4 nm. The decreased size after reaction can be related to the reaction-induced reshaping of Ni nanocrystals during the growth of carbon filaments [67]. Compared with NiAl and Ni/Al2O3, the amount of coke on NiCaAl was higher. In the XRD pattern of the fresh and oxidized NiCaAl (Fig. S6a), Ca3Al2O6, Ca2Al2SiO7 and weakly-bonded NiO were detected. In the absence of forming NiO-Al2O3 solid solution with strong interaction, it was suggested that the Ca reduced the interaction strength between Ni and Al2O3, making NiCaAl less coke resistant. The promotion of coke formation by Ca species on NiCaAl was in agreement with the report by Jin et al. [68]. On spent Ni/ZSM-5, a high C-Ni fraction of 40.9 % was obtained from XPS analysis, which was opposed to the low coke content. The contradictory results suggest that coke deposition on Ni/ZSM-5 was limited by the steric constraint of the micropores instead of coke promotion by the acid sites [69]. In the case of Ni/TiO2, low coke formation was observed. The low fraction of C-Ni bond (Fig. 9i, Table 2) indicates that the active Ni sites may be covered by TiO2 due to the support encapsulation [31], which may also lead to the low syngas yield over Ni/TiO2. Among the investigated catalysts, Ni/MgO showed the highest coke resistance. There are two reasons: (1) coke formation was inhibited without the generation of large Ni aggregates from MgO-NiO solid solution; (2) the basic nature of MgO reduced the rate of coke formation on the support. Overall, the results showed that the coke deposition was strongly influenced by the supports, which was prone to form on the catalysts with weak metal-support interaction. 3.5 Reaction mechanism during reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles For the tested Ni catalysts, coke formation was dependent on the supports and the unique metal-support interaction. However, coking is an undesirable side reaction during steam reforming that can cause severe degradation of catalyst activity and mechanical strength. In the presence of the complex hydrocarbons, there is a thermodynamic potential for coke formation. According to Rostrup-Nielsen et al. [54], a couple of reactions were possibly involved, as follows: (7) 2 CO = C + C O 2 Δ H ° 298 = − 172 k J m o l − 1 (8) CO + H 2 = C + H 2 O Δ H ° 298 = − 131 k J m o l − 1 (9) C H 4 = C + 2 H 2 Δ H ° 298 = + 75 k J m o l − 1 (10) C n H m = n C + m / 2 H 2 (11) C n H m = olefins = c o k e During the high temperature reforming at 800 °C, coke formation via reactions (7) and (8) were not thermodynamically favored because of the exothermic nature. It seems that the coke deposit mainly originated from reaction (11) other than reactions (9) and (10), due to the higher tendency of olefinic C2H4 for coke formation compared to other hydrocarbons [70,71]. The composition of produced syngas from LDPE pyrolysis volatiles was influenced by several reactions. Hydrocarbon decomposition (Eq. (10)) produced additional H2. However, high H2/CO ratio was obtained over Ni/TiO2 which was relatively coke resistant, suggesting that hydrocarbon decomposition played an insignificant role in increasing H2/CO ratio. It is most likely that the H2/CO ratio higher than 2 resulted from the water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (12)) by producing additional H2 while converting CO to CO2. (12) CO + H 2 O = CO 2 + H 2 Δ H ° 298 = - 41 k J m o l - 1 According to Wang et al. [56], catalyst on reducible supports had higher activity for water-gas shift reaction compared to the catalysts on non-reducible supports. The high H2/CO ratio observed over Ni/TiO2 should result from the reducible nature of TiO2 by forming highly active Ni-TiO2 interface. However, it was also observed that the CO selectivity over Ni catalyst on reducible CeO2 was comparable to Ni/Al2O3. The inconsistent observation can be explained by the higher coke deposition on Ni/CeO2 compared to Ni/Al2O3, which reduced the amount of accessible interfacial site for the water-gas shift reaction. In addition to water-gas shift reaction, Boudouard reaction (Eq. (7)) also produces CO2 by the disproportionation of CO. However, this reaction was not favored due to its exothermic nature. According to Hunt et al. [72], the equilibrium of Boudouard reaction favors the production of CO instead of CO2 at temperatures higher than 700 °C. For the catalyst with high coke content (NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3), the generated CO2 from the water-gas shift reaction can participate in the gasification of coke, forming CO. This suggests that the reverse Boudouard reaction can compromise the effect of water-gas shift reaction, leading to increased CO selectivity and lower H2/CO ratio. Alternatively, the coke can be directly gasified by the steam (Eq. (13)). (13) C + H 2 O = CO + H 2 Δ H ° 298 = + 131 k J m o l − 1 However, this reaction is irrelevant to the CO/CO2 selectivity as it can be considered as the total reaction of water-gas shift reaction and reverse Boudouard reaction. To sum up, water-gas shift reaction predominately influenced the H2/CO ratio and CO selectivity during steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles, the effect of which was compromised by the reverse Boudouard reaction. 3.6 Overview of catalyst supports for reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles Table 3 summarizes the effects of supports on the performance of the investigated Ni catalysts. The metal-support interaction is one of the influential factors on the catalyst activity and coke formation. For Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3, both catalysts had good activity and high coke deposition, which were promoted by the weak metal-support interaction. For the catalysts with strong metal interaction with the supports, e.g., Al2O3 and MgO, the coke deposition was lower. However, due to the distinctiveness of various supports, the catalytic performance could be affected by other properties of the catalysts, such as metal particle size, reduction degree, porous structure and the resistance to metal oxidation. To compare the performance of the Ni catalysts, syngas yield and coke content are plotted in Fig. 10 . NiAl was selected as the reference for the comparison because it is a commercial catalyst and has better performance than NiCaAl. As shown in Table S2, NiAl has higher Ni content than the other catalysts (16.8 wt.% against 9.5–11.3 wt.%). However, the reforming activity and coke formation on NiAl was lower than NiCaAl, Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3, suggesting that the catalyst performance was influenced by other factors rather than the Ni content only. A possible explanation is that the catalyst activity and coke formation were influenced by the Ni particle size and the catalyst reduction degree on the different supports with varied metal-support interaction. From Fig. 10, the catalysts can be categorized into three groups using NiAl as the reference. Ni/SiO2 and NiCaAl locating at the upper left are the least suitable catalysts because of the lower syngas yield and higher coke formation compared to NiAl. For the other catalysts, the high coke formation on Ni/CeO2 and Ni/Y2O3 (upper right) and the low activity on Ni/ZSM-5 and Ni/TiO2 (lower left) made them less suitable for steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles. The coke can result in severe catalyst deactivation by blocking the catalytic active sites and increase the pressure drop, which may lead to process failure [73]. Considering the excellent catalytic activity for syngas, Ni/CeO2 could be an option for steam reforming if coke formation can be reduced by either catalyst modification or optimizing the process condition, including the reaction temperature, steam to hydrocarbon ratio, space velocity, etc. Among the prepared catalysts, Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgO are potential candidates for long term operation owning to the high coke resistance. However, performance improvements are still desirable over these catalysts, i.e., further reducing coke formation on Ni/Al2O3, and increasing the activity of Ni/MgO. 4 Conclusion In the present work, a series of Ni catalysts with various supports are prepared and investigated in steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles for syngas production. The supports have shown fundamental effects on catalytic activity, selectivity and coke formation. Ni/CeO2 was found the most active catalyst, followed by alumina-supported catalysts and Ni/Y2O3, while Ni/MgO, Ni/TiO2, Ni/SiO2, and Ni/ZSM-5 were the least active. Weak metal interaction with Y2O3 and CeO2 favored high coke deposition. The catalysts with medium (Ni/ZSM-5 and Ni/TiO2) and strong metal interaction (Ni/MgO and Ni/Al2O3) were more resistant to coking. Formation of graphitic coke was favored from the LDPE-derived volatiles, and steam to LDPE mass ratio of 2 resulted in high concentration of defects in the coke. It was also found that light olefins were more reactive on Ni catalysts than light alkanes during the catalytic steam reforming process. Correlating the H2/CO ratio with CO selectivity, it has been demonstrated that the supports significantly influenced the composition of produced syngas via the water-gas shift reaction and reverse Boudouard reaction. Among the various catalysts, Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/MgO appear as potential candidates for syngas production from steam reforming of LDPE pyrolysis volatiles. coredata.dc:description: Syngas is a valuable intermediate for sustainable management of waste plastics, which can be converted to new monomers and chemicals. In this work, Ni catalysts were studied for syngas recovery via steam reforming of low-density polyethylene (LDPE) pyrolysis volatiles on various supports, such as Al2O3, MgO, CeO2, Y2O3, TiO2, SiO2 and ZSM-5. Two commercial catalysts (NiAl and NiCaAl) were used for comparison. The supports exhibited distinct effects on the catalytic activity, selectivity and coke formation. Ni/CeO2, Ni/Y2O3, Ni/Al2O3, NiAl and NiCaAl showed high syngas yield but these catalysts were prone to coke formation. Ni/MgO, Ni/TiO2, Ni/SiO2 and Ni/ZSM-5 were the least active. The obtained H2/CO ratios were correlated with CO selectivity, revealing the unique impacts of supports on syngas composition via water-gas shift reaction. Compared with commercial NiAl, our work demonstrated that the prepared Ni catalysts on Al2O3 and MgO were suitable candidates for steam reforming of plastic pyrolysis volatiles.
coredata.dc:title: Support effects on thermocatalytic pyrolysis-reforming of polyethylene over impregnated Ni catalysts
